captions.text:
- People taking your
mail, that's not okay.

That's something we gotta
confront as a society.
(whimsical folk music)
- I cry every time I watch Harry Potter,
so we'll see if this does it for me.

- A lot of chiseled white
people falling in love.
- Gosling's got balls, she's into it.
Whoa, this dude's creepy!
- Say it.
- I wanna go out with you!
- That is psychotic.
If someone did that in real life,
I would just assume that there were like
body parts in his freezer.

- This guy's always
pulling stunts, isn't he?

What'd you do on your
date tonight, sweetheart?
Oh, laid in the road.

- [Man in blue shirt] Be
careful, you'll cut yourself
on his chiseled jaw line.

- Now people say stuff
like, "Call me daddy."

They used to say stuff
like, "Say I'm a bird."

- [Man in blue shirt]
Look at that mustache!
- I work at the lumberyard.

- You don't ask somebody
how much money they make.
He's gonna show her his Gosling.
- Did you just hear that?
- [Man in white shirt] What?
- He said, "I love you."
- I love you, too.
(men exclaiming approval and excitement)
- She said she loved him.
- Trash, not for you.

(men exclaiming in disgust
and feigned surprise)

- [Man in blue shirt]
Class war, class war.
- Oh, class war.
(Alli grunting)
- Oh, she broke that.
(all groaning in sympathy)
- Damn you, Marsden, damn you

and your perfect jawline
and your dreamy eyes!
- [Man in green shirt] Oh don't kiss him.
- [Man in white shirt] No, no, no.
- Why?

- Okay, she has salon-quality
hair after being (bleep).
- Paint naked.
- [Man in plaid shirt] God.
(all exclaiming with titillation)
(whooping)

- She's gonna take her
down to the lumber mill,
and show her how the other half lives.

At any point in time,
she could have been like,

here you go, and she didn't,
every single day for a year.

- I'm just saying a handwritten
letter isn't creepy,

because I've done it, and
I'm hoping it's not creepy.
- Stop thinking about what I want,
what he wants, what your parents want.
What do you want?

- What does she want?
- What does she want?

- God, this was like,
amazingly depressing.
- I can see why everyone in 2004
was really hyped-up on The Notebook.
- Pick a lumberyard boy.
- It was so sad.

- The quality spirit comes
from lumberyard boys,
is I guess is what I'm trying to say.
- Love isn't actually like this,
but we want it to be.
- [Man in green shirt] That's not true!

You watch this movie and you
think of that special someone,

try to be half as good as
half those guys, you know?
- Little bit of a Ryan Gosling fan,

little bit of a Drive fan,
decided to watch the Notebook.
Wondering if he shoots anybody in this.
It looks like he's gonna shot some people.

title: Guys Watch The Notebook For The First Time

comments.author: areedhel

comments.text:
I dunno, it was touching-ish the first time I watched it. But like The 
Butterfly Effect, the second time I watched it, I sat with a look of horror 
and wondered how the hell I wasn't deeply disturbed the first time through. 
Like, that's a seriously fucked up relationship they got going on there. 
And I guess they figured it out sometime between screaming at each other 
and hitting each other every ten minutes and the Alzheimer's... All the 
same, the fact we romanticize that early stage as ~*~The Ideal Romance~*~ 
as a society really freaks me out.﻿
comments.author: Pearl Carol

comments.text:
+Pearl Carol They're passioned about each other. The saddest and greatest 
thing about our race, is that we can get different perspective of the same 
thing. In this case what you call screaming at each other or hitting, I'm 
not saying it's right, but what I got from it, is passion, and frustration, 
and the first time you deal with it as a teenager. And how time passed, the 
same idealized love, we all want remained. That's what it made it a great 
book and a good romantic movie. It's not what type of romance, or how they 
deal with it that, people fantasize about. Is just that kind of love, that 
simple ignites your soul (wich normally doesn't include the hitting or 
screaming)
